question: Amar natash bow basar! -- Rescind from the flesh I command thee -- The girl chokes as if ready to spit. That's it -- time to go home. Jeanie SCREAMS -- Amar natash bow basar -- Another PULSE and this time a SHAPE is clearly seen expanding under the child's skin -- as if the demon inside were trying to burst right through. John backs off -- watches as the shape ripples her flesh, like fingers caressing from the other side. John glances to Hennessey. What the hell? MIRROR arrives at the doorway, BANGS against the JAM. John waves them in. The four men heft it into the room. Lift it. Over the bed. Up. Hennessey, tie it off -- Hennessey is glad to be called into service -- quickly ties one end of rope to the mirror. John straddles the girl, positions his head between her and the mirror above him. Now close your eyes -- all of you -- and whatever happens -- do not look into the mirror. The men close their eyes. Muscles tense under the weight. Amar natash bow basar! -- rescind from the flesh I command thee! Jeanie reacts -- that SHAPE reappears, contorts the young body all out of proportion. John unblocks the mirror for a second and Jeanie is reflected inside. It's not just the image of a young girl in there, but something else. The surface of the mirror FLEXES in the hands of the men. One starts to look -- No! Jeanie SCREAMS -- breaks free of the straps. She rises up, grabs John tight around the throat. Nails dig deep.
answer: John?!

question: Not yet! John struggles, puts his hands over her mouth -- cutting off her air supply. Question is, who's going to pass out first? Jeanie's body is racked by whatever's inside her. She goes into shock, body collapsing -- shaking -- close to death. Look! Look at me! But she's passing out first. John quickly takes the medallion that caused the earlier reaction -- Goddamit -- look! -- and presses it against her forehead. Eyes snap wide and John unblocks the mirror. Jeanie locks on her reflection and the image in the mirror changes drastically. Smile pretty you vain prick. The child's reflection has now changed to a pissed off DEMON. One that knows it just got suckered in. MIRROR VIBRATES wildly in the men's grip. Demon reflection ripples the glass -- bending it outward into three-D space as the girl takes her last breaths -- Now, Hennessey. Now! Hennessey PULLS the rope with all three-hundred-plus pounds as John gives the demon face a full extended For your boss. Demon pushes for him but mirror is jerked into motion. Swings right out the window but catches on a sliver of wood -- No you don't. John jumps up and helps push the mirror free.
answer: Now about the fee... John slips FROM VIEW into the kitchenette, hides the fact that he has to lean against the door to keep his balance. He catches his breath, looks up and is staring right at a child's crayon drawing magneted to the fridge. A drawing of a figure poking another in the side with a long stick. This image is repeated over and over. John tugs it off the fridge, tucks it away. Thank you. Yes... Gracias...

question: Hennessey. Hennessey stops his panhandling, continues toward the exit.
answer: I know, I know, but I didn't think she was really possessed, not like that.

question: I'm not back an hour and you drag me into --
answer: -- Don't be mad, John, don't be -- John rummages through his coat pockets -- On the left side. John keeps searching. Vest pocket. John rips his smokes from the left vest pocket --

question: Don't do that shit on me --
answer: Sorry, sorry. Here, you can have half. Hennessey starts to divvy the cash but John snatches the hat.

question: I should take it all, save you from yourself. He gestures that bagged BOTTLE in Hennessey's jacket.
answer: It keeps them out, so I can sleep. Please, John, I need to sleep. John stares at his pathetic friend, sighs, finally slips a few bills from the wad and hands them over. Hennessey is bubbling with appreciation, starts to follow. John simply holds up a hand. Hennessey stops, watches John walk out. Alone.

question: I told you to move it.
answer: Well maybe if you had told me you were dropping a three-hundred pound mirror with a pissed-off demon in it I would have moved it further. Chaz slams the hood. They slide into the car. Well?

question: Well what? Chaz reaches back into John's front coat pocket -- pulls out Hennessey's wad of cash -- slips off a few bills.
answer: Shouldn't have cut your stay in the land of enlightenment. You were so close to growing a conscience. John grins, pulls his special lighter, lights a smoke and sits back.

question: You still with me?
answer: Yeah... The MAN is thirty feet down the same track. Their VOICES ECHO off the curved walls, come from everywhere. How either of these two got here isn't important. Who will get out is.

question: So what's next, Detective? We gonna do a full marathon? Intermittent RADIO CHATTER buzzes from Angela's WALKIE- TALKIE. You get the sense Angela is not alone in here.
answer: Put your weapon on the tracks and step out with your hands above your head.

question: Or how 'bout you show yourself and I put a bullet in your skull just like I did hers!
answer: That's just not going to happen.

question: You sure about that?! Angela checks the chamber -- sees she has one bullet left.
answer: Now put down your weapon on the tracks and -- GROUND BEGINS to VIBRATE. Tunnel starts to GLOW.

question: There are four bags. I have two hands. This give you any ideas?
answer: Make two trips? John walks in. Chaz curses under his breath.

question: Simple question. How much longer do I have to be your slave? John pulls a chain and a wall of window shutters open.
answer: You're not my slave, Chaz. You're my very appreciated assistant. Like Tonto and Robin and that skinny fellow with the fat friend. Along the floor, encircling the entire room, are 5 gallon Sparkletts bottles. Each is adorned by a small hand- marked CROSS. John takes a moment to adjust one out of place.

question: How much longer? John doesn't like his tone.
answer: Well I don't know, what's the going rate for saving a taxi driver hanging from his fingernails about to be swallowed into the jaws of Hell?

question: So what time you want me back? John gives him a knowing look, goes back to emptying his pockets.
answer: I need to make an appearance at Midnite's. Say ten-ish? Chaz sighs, starts out -- Chaz...? Chaz turns back, catches an object John throws him. A little something from Delphi. It's a dashboard air freshener shaped like a cow. Chaz tips it. Moooooo. John finds it rather amusing.

question: 'Provisions depleted?' John turns to see BEEMAN waddle in. I gave you three months worth. You were gone only one. This diminutive occult version of Bond's "Q" carries a custom bowling bag and squints in the light like a mole.
answer: What can I say, Beeman, India was a real drain. They shake hands. Beeman sets his bowling bag onto the table, unzips it.

question: So what do you need?
answer: Everything you got.

question: You smell something, John?
answer: Maybe. Incubus in this girl I just exorcized seemed a bit more spirited than usual. Beeman starts pulling things out. First is a frayed RAG. Then glass containers...

question: Well, I've got your stone fragments from the Road to Damascus, dust from the Dead Sea Scrolls -- oh, you'll love this -- Out comes a little MATCHBOX with a smiling bug graphic. Screech beetle from Mount Sinai. He shakes the matchbox and the BEETLE flutters inside. It's WINGS create an eerie HIGH-PITCHED WHIRL. John shrugs. So? Yeah, to you it's nothing but to the Fallen -- like fingernails on a chalkboard.
answer: What is it with you and bugs? Beeman pulls out a set of sculptured BRASS KNUCKLES. Actually solid gold and engraved with religious markings. John takes them, tries them on. Nice fit.

question: Gold was blessed by the Bishop Anicott during the Crusades. John spots a foot-long COPPER TUBE in the bag, pulls it out, grips the bicycle handle on one end. Watch it there. With this puny little thing? John gives the handle a squeeze and WHOOOOSH -- ten-foot FLAME BELCHES out. Dragon's breath.
answer: I thought you couldn't get it anymore. Beeman shrugs, modesty. John starts to put it down on the table and Beeman quickly pulls the frayed rag away.

question: Whoa, don't want to get a flame near this. Piece of the shroud Moses wore to the mountain. John picks it up -- You're shitting me, right? Nope.
answer: Got any callinicus?

question: How spirited was this incubus?
answer: Like it was trying to come right out through the girl Beeman just stares at him -- is this a joke? I know how it sounds...

question: We're finger puppets to them, John, elaborate costumes -- they can work us but don't come through us. They can't. You know that.
answer: Check the scrolls anyway. Corinthians. See if there are any precedents.

question: Sure, John. Anything else?
answer: Wouldn't happen to have anything for -- Beeman sets down a bottle from the bag -- Vick's 44.

question: Gutsy move out there, Dodson. Angela glances at DETECTIVE WEISS as he opens his locker.
answer: Gutsy? Well that's a new one. The two exchange a look.

question: You're alive. Bad guy's dead. No point in using the other words.
answer: Thanks.

question: Even though it was reckless -- irresponsible -- stupid...
answer: I knew you still cared.

question: You're good, Angela, real good but one of these days...
answer: I know, nobody's luck lasts forever. He meets her eyes. Exactly. He really does care. Weiss breaks it off, leaves. Angela turns to close her locker door, notices her reflection does not turn. She grabs the door, looks back in. Reflection is as it should be. She shudders, slams the locker door.

question: Numquam leadatur a morsu. A living GROAN BELLOWS from the rigid seams but the doors don't budge. Bastard changed the code again. Midnite! Come on, do I have to huff and puff here?! The doors unlatch.
answer: Et separatur a plasmate tuo, Ut num quam laedatur amorsu antiqui serpentes... John steps in through the doors behind.

question: Deciding which color to paint this place again? PAPPA MIDNITE stands in the jungle he calls an office. Part African witch doctor, part savvy businessman. A full six and half feet of solid contradictions.
answer: You're back early.

question: I got tired of spending your money.
answer: But I'm sure you spent enough.

question: Well I do have a certain standard of living.
answer: Tell me you found it.

question: I found the vault.
answer: That's not what I asked.

question: Hey, can I help it if Buddhist monks don't take bribes? Midnite strides toward him when John calmly pulls from his pocket a small ebony and gold RELIC. It stops Midnite cold. Gotcha. A reluctant grin cracks Midnite's stern features. He takes the relic in his thick fingers -- stares breathlessly at a gaunt figure bracing itself against a cosmic wind.
answer: Second century depiction of a sephiroth in the 4th realm...

question: Right. So we good here? Midnite ignores his outstretched palm, slides the relic precisely onto one of the many rods jutting from the Universal orrery.
answer: It should counter the iconic plane --

question: That damn thing's never going to balance. Midnite lets go and the complex machine actually starts to move. To turn.
answer: Must I remind you of what selling fake relics will do to your health?

question: It's authentic, Midnite, you just have the wrong piece. Jesus... The two have a mini stare-down. John's rigid poker face is only broken by a cough. Midnite sighs, breaks it off. What? -- I didn't blink -- that was a cough. You never cough? Midnite reaches into his tuxedo jacket and hands over a thick stack of HUNDREDS. Better not be any Washingtons in here this time.
answer: Why did you cut your trip short? John stops the counting, actually thinks about it.

question: I don't know... Just a feeling -- John suddenly spins toward the entrance doors, is stunned to see -- Balthazar. Balthazar is behind him. Utterly confident. Chillingly so.
answer: We're not still whining about Manhattan, are we? John's attempt to disguise his anger fails. That expression alone has made my entire night.

question: I'll make your night -- I'll deport your sorry ass right where you stand -- It's bad enough that you let these half-breeds in at all but this piece of shit --
answer: Perks of becoming a primary investor.

question: What?! Midnite's eyes say it all -- not here, not now.
answer: Things change, balances shift. Get used to it, Constantine.

question: Not while I'm still breathing -- John starts to cough again.
answer: I'm sorry, I didn't catch that. John tries to catch his breath, can't. And that scares him a bit. He tries to hide it, pushes out.

question: Hey, John. I'm real sorry about this morning, John, real sorry. Please don't hate me for draggin' you into that. Please don't... John can finally breathe.
answer: I don't hate you.

question: That's good to hear. Real good...
answer: But could you at least wait until I call for you before you show up?

question: You didn't call?
answer: Not yet. Jesus, Hennessey, you freak me out sometimes.

question: So you want me to go away and come back?
answer: No. I've got an assignment for you.

question: Really? What kind of assignment?
answer: The kind you'll have to be sober for.

question: Oh God, you want me to surf the ether. He instinctively touches an AMULET around his neck. Four intersecting crosses.
answer: Come on, you know that exorcism wasn't right.

question: I... I don't have the Sight anymore.
answer: Don't have it or don't want to use it? Hennessey vacillates. This is obviously tough for him. Just look around. A few days. You spot anything unusual, anything -- you let me know. Okay? John wraps an arm around his shoulder like a good buddy, then reaches behind his neck -- It'll be like old times. -- and unclips the amulet from Hennessey's neck. That unnerves the big guy. John drops it in Hennessey's pocket. Just for a few days.

question: I killed a man today. Another one. FATHER GARRET sits on the other side of the mesh window.
answer: I'm sorry, Angela.

question: Most cops go twenty years without firing their gun. Not me. I always seem to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. I didn't even see his face. I just pulled the trigger and he went away. Just like all the others... Angela in the SHOWER -- trying to wash off the guilt.
answer: These feelings are natural in your line of work, Angela. I'd be worried if you didn't have them. Angela now in a recliner, cat in her lap. She's tired. Eyes are heavy. But you have to be strong. You can't allow your faith to be overshadowed by guilt.

question: I'm trying. Her eyes close. I'm trying real hard.
answer: It's her, Angela... It's Isabel. They arrive at the covered body in the courtyard. Coroner sees Angela approach and lifts the sheet from the face. Angela comes to a dead stop, emotions coming fast and furious. She leans close and we see a mirror of Angela. That's when you realize that wasn't a dream. This is her twin. But that circular symbol is nowhere on her wrist now. Angela's eyes well with tears. It takes everything she has to stay in control. Helps to wrap herself in the job. She steps back, looks up at the tall building.

question: She... she fell from the roof?
answer: No. She jumped. Angela gives him an incredulous glare. Shakes her head. I know it's hard to accept but --

question: Isabel would never in a million years take her own life. Never.
answer: Angela... there was a surveillance camera on the roof. Take some time... Angela brushes off his hand, then spots Weiss and the others on the other side of the room. Whose hand was that?

question: Not if I can help it. The doors close right on Angela.
answer: Lung cancer? Lung cancer?! John turns to see ELLIE strutting up the sidewalk. Uninhibited. Oozing sex appeal. But dangerous. In more ways than you think. That's funny as shit, John.

question: As if you guys didn't have something to do with it...
answer: Hey, I think you brought this one on yourself. John stares at her, tries to get a read. Now why wouldn't you trust me?

question: I don't know, something in the air -- She sits right on his lap, playfully.
answer: Don't worry, John, you'll beat this. You beat everything.

question: Not this time, Ellie. John lifts her off of him, sets her aside.
answer: Oh wow, you're serious... No wonder the Boss is in such a good mood.

question: Yeah, I thought maybe you could talk to him for me. You know...?
answer: What?! Dammit, John, I know I owe you but to even ASK that? All those saints and martyrs slipping through his grasp -- his own foot soldiers sent back to him in chunks. He's going to take all that out on you, John, and he's going to enjoy ripping your soul to shreds until the end of time.

question: So I take that as a 'no?'
answer: You're the one soul the man himself would actually come up here to collect. And you know how much he despises this place.

question: I'm starting to see his point. Ellie sits back down, strokes his arm.
answer: Have you gone to see the Snob? Like scratching fingers across a blackboard. No way. Look, don't let your ego get in the way on this. I'd miss having someone up here I can... relate to. She gives him a kiss. And for a second John's leg is brushed by a tail. John doesn't react. Just turns and walks away.

question: So you're rude no matter where you are. John gives her a look. The two men shake hands and start to part. John and Angela make their move toward the men. Both are surprised when Angela goes for Father Garret and John goes for -- -- the SNOB, officially known as GABRIEL. Yes, that one.
answer: and Angela have retreated to another area for privacy.

question: Why is he stalling on this? My sister needs a Catholic funeral.
answer: Angela, it's still considered a mortal sin --

question: She didn't commit suicide.
answer: The Bishop has read otherwise.

question: Father... David -- this is Isabel. Please... Father Garret stares at her, tries to be compassionate.
answer: I'll talk to him again. But Angela has just lost a load of faith.

question: I know what you want, son.
answer: Been keeping your all-seeing eye on me, have you?

question: I could offer how a shepherd leads even the most wayward of his flock but it might sound disingenuous.
answer: So you're going to make me beg? Angela pauses on her way out, looks over.

question: It wouldn't help. You've already wasted your chance at redemption.
answer: What about the minions I've sent back, the souls that I've saved -- that should guarantee my passage across --

question: -- No -- passage requires faith and faith by definition is belief without proof. You have proof. And that means you're not playing by the same rules as everyone else. Your work has mostly been for selfish reasons. I'm sorry.
answer: This is bullshit -- bullshit! Now he's really got Angela's attention. It's like you've got some cosmic scale weighing everything we do -- help an old lady across the street -- put in a nickel, kick a dog, take out a dime -- you're fucking nickel and diming us to death down here!

question: Keep your voice down.
answer: And you know what, you're the ones with the problem, not us -- You make these impossible rules to decide who goes up, who goes down and you don't even understand us -- This more than anything gets under Gabriel's skin.

question: Each of you is born with the promise of salvation preordained. The cost of your redemption is simple belief. And yet you whine about impossible rules. Sometimes I imagine you hardly deserve the gift you have been given.
answer: Gift?! More like a curse the way you manage things. Gabriel stands and towers over John.

question: I am taking your situation into account, John, but don't push me.
answer: Why me, Gabriel? It's personal, isn't it? I didn't go to church enough? I didn't pray enough? I was five bucks short in the collection plate? Why? Gabriel moves right up to him, makes this very personal.

question: You're going to die because you smoked 30 cigarettes a day since you were 15. And you're going to Hell because of the life you took. Or to put it in a way that your kind would understand. You're fucked.
answer: He has a rotten sense of humor. And his punch lines are killers. John tosses the cigarette pack, walks right into the RAIN, away from Chaz's taxi pulling up.

question: A few months, maybe a year. That's it. End of story. Game over. Well, don't break down on my account.
answer: What do you want from me? A shoulder to cry on?

question: This bastard attacked me right out in the open -- on Sepulveda no less.
answer: They don't like you, John. You've deported how many back to Hell?

question: That's just it -- this wasn't some possession or wayward half breed, it was a full-fledged demon. Here. On our plane.
answer: Right.

question: I know what I saw.
answer: You must have just crossed over and didn't even realize it --

question: I didn't cross over -- It was on this side. Here.
answer: -- it's wet out, you're wandering around aimlessly, not to mention completely emotional --

question: Emotional?! John slams a fist against the counter. The orrery almost topples but Midnite saves it. Decades of work almost lost. Midnite glares at a desperate John.
answer: Okay, so you saw something. We've seen a few small ones slip through now and then.

question: It's more than that... first the girl, then this.
answer: John, you know my connections. Any shifts or tremors in the planes and I'd hear about it. John just shakes his head, looks up -- convinced.

question: Something's coming. Midnite sighs, gives up with him.
answer: L.A.P.D. This is Dodson, hello? Dead air. The next PHONE RINGS. Angela reaches for it when the NEXT ONE RINGS, and the NEXT, the NEXT. The RINGS HOP phone to phone in intimidating mockery. Angela freezes, forces herself to stay calm. Sure enough, the RINGS abruptly CEASE. Angela reaches over, rips the page from the printer, leaves.

question: Welcome to my life.
answer: Mr. Constantine? John looks up, spots Angela. Those eyes again. I saw you at --

question: -- I remember.
answer: And --

question: Yeah.
answer: I'd like to ask you a few questions.

question: I'm not really in the talking mood right now.
answer: Could you just listen then? Angela sets her LAPD detective badge on the table. Please?

question: Always a catch... Angela sits across from him, puts the badge away.
answer: My sister was murdered last week.

question: Sorry to hear...
answer: Her name was Isabel. Isabel Dodson? She looks for a reaction. None. You don't remember her?

question: Never met her.
answer: You sure?

question: She look anything like you? I would've remembered. Another beat as their eyes meet. John looks away.
answer: She was a patient at Ravenscar. Then last Tuesday she just decided to step off the roof.

question: I thought you said she was murdered?
answer: Isabel would never take her own life.

question: You'd be surprised at what people will do.
answer: Look, I know I'm not making much sense -- hell I'm not really sure what I'm doing here... I just feel -- the circles you travel in -- the occult, demonology, exorcisms... John just stares at that spider in the glass. Trapped. I believe someone got to her, Mr. Constantine, brainwashed her into stepping off that roof. Some kind of legion or cult.

question: Sounds like a theory. Good luck.
answer: Well I thought with your background and experience, you could at least point me in the right direction.

question: Yeah, okay. Sure. John points -- toward the exit. Angela is not amused. But she's not giving up.
answer: My sister always talked about a world better than this. Heaven as some call it. She wasn't afraid of dying because she knew it was waiting for her. What everyone fails to grasp is that if she had really taken her own life --

question: -- she would have committed a mortal sin and her soul would have gone straight to Hell where it would never feel love or compassion or anything but pain again as the master himself rips her apart over and over for the rest of eternity. That about right? The words have hit so hard that Angela is speechless. John sees the hurt in her eyes, would like to take it back -- but it's too late. She turns and starts out, slows --
answer: You're not the only one afraid of Hell. John tries not to let that get to him. She leaves. He glances out the window, watches her pass by. So long. Good riddance. But something's not right. Those deep shadows on the buildings seem to be moving. John watches, confused, realizes they're heading in Angela's direction.

question: Oh shit... He stands, gains his bearings. As he walks out he flicks the glass over. Spider runs free. Detective! Angela looks back, sees John in the street. How open is your mind? Do you believe in Heaven and Hell? How about what comes out of each? Angela keeps walking. He catches up with her. Hey!
answer: You mean like angels?

question: And demons. Angela stares at him, continues walking. He keeps up. See, you don't have the mindset for this kind of work. They walk together down the lonely street.
answer: Look, I see terrible things every day. A mother drowns her baby. A ten-year-old shoots his father. But it's not demons, it's the evil that men do. Behind them, a streetlight BLINKS OUT. Then another. They're not looking back so they don't see it.

question: You're right, we're capable of terrible things but we usually justify it with motives like money and power and jealousy. Another LIGHT FIZZES, blinks out. Then sometimes, something comes along and gives us just the right nudge and we do truly evil things just for the kick of it.
answer: I don't believe in demons.

question: You should. They believe in us. They pass another streetlamp as it goes bright, then blacks out. Both look up. The next LAMP FLARES then FIZZES OUT. Angela turns and sees that there are no lights behind them. She looks to John. But he's staring straight ahead. Because now the light in front of them is FLARING We should go... Second later it BLINKS OFF. John grabs her hand -- Fast. Angela's confusion turns to tension as a raspy guttural WIND races toward them. John jerks her into action. They run towards the next light. It blinks out right when they reach it. They race to stay in the light, aiming toward the safety of the brightly-lit statue of the Good Shepherd.
answer: What is that?

question: Wings.
answer: Wings? John rummages through his trench coat -- fishes out that cloth Beeman gave him. The one supposedly wrapped around Moses.

question: And maybe talons. The cross is getting dimmer and dimmer...
answer: Are you kidding? Of what?

question: Something that's not supposed to be here. John quickly wraps the cloth tight around his hand. Angela spins, eyes seeing only darkness as the sounds get CLOSER -- ghastly sound of MOVEMENT in the fringes of light. The cross now resembles a dying wire filament and with every second the circle of light gets smaller and those SOUNDS GET CLOSER. John takes out his special lighter. Close your eyes. They are now standing in pitch darkness.
answer: Why?

question: Suit yourself. John flicks the lighter and in one powerful motion -- sweeps his arm up as he lights his hand. Sacred cloth catches fire -- then IGNITES with a brilliant retina-searing FLASH -- blinding Angela and illuminating a -- -- CIRCLE OF WINGED DEMONS -- a roiling broth of reptilian death -- right there -- ready to pounce. 'I accidentally crossed over?' I don't think so.
answer: What was that? I saw wings -- and teeth -- they were flying. What the hell were those things?!

question: They weren't angels. John scans the area, trying to think this through. Seplavites, actually. Scavengers for the damned. Demons?
answer: What? You can't be serious... this is impossible...

question: Yeah... And I don't think they were after me... John looks at her with renewed interest. You really believe she wouldn't commit suicide?
answer: My sister? Never in a million years. John makes the decision.

question: Let's be sure. He starts walking. Angela is now compelled to follow.
answer: How?

question: Simple. See if she's in Hell.
answer: These are all Isabel's things.

question: The cat too?
answer: Yeah, why...? John ignores the box of items, picks up the cat. He studies it a bit, then sits back in a chair with it. Don't you need candles and a pentagram for this to work?

question: Why, do you have any? John puts his feet, shoes and all into a BUCKET OF WATER. I need you to step outside now. Angela? Please. Angela reluctantly moves toward the exit. John holds the cat, stares into its huge, unblinking eyes. There's a moment where animal and man seem to connect. The water around John's feet begins to BOIL. ANGELA pushes the door closed behind her but it slows on its way to latch. Bulbs pulsate as current ramps down. The room flickers, is suddenly caught in a ghostly dim half-light and John has now crossed over into -- Is she here? On the horizon is a dying RED SUN. It strains to cut through the putrid brown haze. Is she here?! His VOICE REVERBERATES to infinity. It's a simple question! Is she here or not?!! John suddenly locks on something far off. On top of a distant skyscraper is a FEMALE FIGURE in a sheer white gown. John can't make out her face but knows she's looking right at him. Isabel? She lifts something and tosses it. John watches as a small object tumbles toward him just ahead of closing darkness. Angela... come back in... Confused, Angela pushes the door back open. Cat BOLTS out. Angela catches her breath, moves inside.
answer: John? What happened? How? How did you do this...? John tries not to stare into those eyes too long. Fails.

question: When I was a kid, I saw things... Things I wasn't supposed to. The man looks right at young John as he passes. His face is distorted and his feet have sprouted roots which are dug into the ground. Tea. She leaves. Angela sits across from him. They're at the table by the window. My parents sent me to a doctor, a shrink, a priest. I was in four different institutions by the time I was eighteen. Angela notes him rubbing his wrist. The last place they put me was run by a church... A DOCTOR rushes past their table. PAN WITH him INTO... The revered Father made the brilliant deduction that I was possessed, said I needed to be exorcised... It was like someone trying to pull teeth that weren't there. Young John clamps his eyes shut tight. So I took things into my own hands and I found a way out.
answer: You attempted suicide. John sees she's looking at his wrist. The hint of a jagged scar can now be seen under the sleeve.

question: I never attempt anything. John's reflection in the window becomes --
answer: But you're still here. Alive.

question: Heaven and Hell are right here, behind every wall, every face -- the world behind the world. It's crossing over that's the real trick. That's why most demons can only whisper in our ears. But even a whisper can turn your favorite pleasure into your worst nightmare. But the worst demons are the ones that are allowed to be here -- the ones that are half-human so they blend in... Balthazar stands, throws a few bills on the table and starts toward the back EXIT. ... just like those with the angel's touch living alongside of us. The half-breeds. That Busboy lowers Hennessey to the floor. For a moment we see him framed against the front doorway. And in that instant we get a brief glimpse of -- They call it 'the Balance.' I call it hypocritical bullshit. So when one of them gets a little cocky, peddles their influence or hijacks a soul -- I deport their scaly ass right back to Hell. I don't get them all but maybe enough to insure my retirement.
answer: Sounds like you're trying to buy your way into Heaven.

question: Well, what would you do if you were sentenced to a prison where half the inmates were put there by you? Not a serene image at all. Angela studies him.
answer: Why you? I mean many go to Hell, why were you able to escape?

question: I don't know.
answer: God has a plan for all of us.

question: Not for me. John's bitterness is obvious. Angela just stares at him -- finally --
answer: Isabel saw things too. John looks up. Moment is lost when her CELLULAR RINGS. The cop in her reacts, flips it open. Detective Dodson here.

question: Shit... Why didn't you call me, you fat sonna bitch... John lowers his head, then spots blood stains on one of Hennessey's hands. He opens the fingers, studies the fork wound. The blood is already drying over it. John reaches over to the mess of dishes on the floor and grabs a melting ice cube. He pushes it into Hennessey's hand, wiping away the dried blood. It quickly becomes apparent -- this isn't random stabbings. This is a shape. John takes a napkin, lays it on the palm and presses. Residual blood creates a symbol onto the napkin. It's the same circular symbol we saw on Isabel's wrist. John doesn't know what it is, but he knows it's important. Rest in peace, Father. I need to see where Isabel died.
answer: Seances, crystals -- channeling... Our father thought she was just trying to get attention. She certainly did that. She'd tell everyone about things she said she saw. Crazy things. Things that hadn't happened yet. She'd scare my mother to death, talking on and on about Revelations and the end of the world. Then one day she just stopped... never said another word.

question: So you put her in here. Angela doesn't need to be reminded. It hurts even more now. Show me her room. You were twins. Angela nods, steps inside. John pauses, thinking. So how long?
answer: Two months. This time. He pulls out a drawer, looks at the bottom. I already did all that. John runs his hands under the steel bed frame. Now you're insulting me.

question: You don't walk off a building without leaving something behind.
answer: You saw everything she left behind. In that box.

question: Maybe she left something else. Something more personal. Just for you. Angela doesn't like that look he's giving her. You were her twin, Angela. Twins tend to think alike.
answer: I'm not like my sister.

question: But you were at once time. When you were kids. When you'd spend every waking hour with each other. You'd start a sentence, she'd finish it. You'd get hurt, she'd cry.
answer: That was a long time ago...

question: That kind of bond doesn't just disappear.
answer: There's nothing here. Angela seems unbalanced. John gets more aggressive.

question: She planned her death in this room, she thought it up right where you're standing -- Angela backs away. John advances. She knew you'd come -- She counted on you to see what she saw, to feel what she felt -- to do what she did. What did she do, Angela?
answer: How should I know?

question: What did she do, Angela?
answer: I don't know!

question: What would you do? Angela backs into a wall. Nowhere else to go now. What would you leave her? What would it be? Where would it be?! Where would it be? Angela lashes out, shoves John hard, pushing him out of her way. She turns to the window, almost hyperventilating. John stays back, watches. Angela opens her eyes. The tension seems to flow right out of her when she sees --
answer: The tree. There must have been a tree in our backyard... when we were kids... John may not be buying it but he's not saying anything. His fingers trace these words carved below the symbol -- Cor?

question: Corinthians.
answer: There is no 14h act in Corinthians. John's face goes pale --

question: I need a church. Corinthians goes to 21 acts in the book of Ethenius. It's like a dark mirror of the Bible. It paints a different view of Revelations, says that the world will not come to an end at the hand of God but be reborn in the embrace of the damned.
answer: There's a difference?

question: Depends on which side of the fence you're standing. John stops, casually sticks his hand in the pastor's bowl of holy water near the altar.
answer: So why haven't I seen this book before?

question: Because it doesn't exist here on this side. John closes his eyes and the water in the bowl begins to
answer: What do you mean -- Flickering candlelight slows to a stop, catching Angela mid-question and the room in that dim half-light. John turns and is inside -- -- not here on this side? John turns, covered in sweat. He's holding a book she's never seen, is already flipping through it. Where did that come from?

question: 13:29. 13:30 -- Here... Corinthians 14:01... 'The sins of the father would only be exceeded by the ego of the son.'
answer: Whose son? John stands, his brain going into overdrive.

question: Symbol isn't a demon's... that's why I couldn't place it... not a normal possession...
answer: John, what are you talking about?

question: But he can't cross over -- impossible for the son to cross over...
answer: Whose son? God's?

question: The myth says Mammon was conceived before his father's fall from grace but was born after. But unlike his old man, he's never been in the presence of the Creator so he has no fear of him, no respect either. That goes double for us -- God's most prized creations. Mammon would be the last demon we'd ever want crossing over.
answer: But demons can't come and go, that's what you said.

question: Unless they found a bridge. Some psychic with the chops to reach all the way to Hell and the grit to withstand whatever shit she'd pull out.
answer: Isabel...

question: But even a bridge wouldn't help Mammon. Because to cross over, the myth says he'd still need the one thing he could never get. Divine assistance. The help of God. Angela sits back, letting that sink in.
answer: So it's impossible.

question: Impossible? Sure it's impossible. That's what makes it so dangerous. These things exist to break the rules, to find the loopholes. If the past is any indication, then the future isn't on our side.
answer: She knew. That's why she killed herself. But it doesn't make sense...

question: Makes sense to me.
answer: John, she sacrificed herself to beat him. John nods. Your point? Why is she in Hell? One of those rare moments where John has no answer.

question: Beeman? John grabs the door that leads behind the pin area. It's locked from the other side. Hey, Beeman? Beeman?! The LOW HUM fluctuates -- sounds like a BUZZING.
answer: Maybe he's not here.

question: He's always here. Several more flies flit by him. This time John notices, turns and spots the source of the HUM -- a cloud of FLIES near the center aisles. Angela follows his gaze, spots them as well.
answer: What? John heads across the lanes. Swarm gets thicker and thicker. Angela keeps up with him, covers her mouth. They approach the pin area of the center lane. The source of the swarm is slowly revealed. In the catch trough is a solid mound of flies. John leans closer, spots a HAND protruding from the mound.

question: Oh Jesus, no -- He rips his coat off, flings it at the mound and million flies scatter -- revealing the body of Beeman. Ravaged. Flies pouring out of his mouth, his ears --
answer: Oh God -- John goes ballistic, screams to the walls --

question: Who are you?! Answer me!! Goddamit -- reveal yourself! I summon you! He angrily rips his sleeves up -- revealing two distinct TATTOOS on his forearms. Slams them together with all his might -- clenching his eyes tight -- concentrating -- Veins in his arms and neck bulge, look ready to explode -- Into the light I command thee!! Into the light I -- John is choked by a cough -- can't finish -- arms separate and he buckles to his knees, reveals to Angela just how ill he really is. She leans down to him, sees hints of blood on the floor. ... this is my fault... I sent them in... I sent them right to their deaths... a damn one-man plague.
answer: John, you need a doctor.

question: I've seen a goddamn doctor!! Angela glares at him -- understands now. He's dying. John stands, almost stumbles. Angela tries to help. Get away from me!!
answer: John?

question: Stay the hell away -- Please -- He uses the handrail to walk away. Angela stands there, confused by her own emotions. She turns back to the carnage, hears the distant SIRENS.
answer: There were no trees in our back yard. John finds Angela across the room in his doorway. But you knew that already, didn't you? John meets her eyes. Sees the questions piling up. You see something in me... Something Isabel had.

question: Go home, Angela.
answer: I need to understand -- John just shakes his head. Why not?

question: Because you open up to that world, you're inviting whatever's out there back in. That's what happened to Isabel.
answer: I'm not Isabel.

question: No, she embraced her gift while you denied yours and that denial is exactly why you're still alive. Stick with me, that'll change. John gets off the window, starts walking away. And I don't need another ghost following me around.
answer: Dammit, John -- they killed my sister! That stops him cold. I can't let them get away with that. Even if it means going down the same path she did. Now if you won't help me get there, I'll find my own way. But I won't run. Never. The two stand there -- locked in this moment. Please... John can't believe this day -- looks her dead in the eye.

question: You do this, there's no turning back. You see them -- they see you. Understand? Angela never blinks as she nods in agreement.
answer: Do I take off my clothes or leave them on? John?

question: I'm thinking.
answer: John.

question: On is fine.
answer: Why water?

question: It's the universal conduit. Lubricates the transition from one plane to another. Now ask me if there's water in Hell. John turns off the faucet. Sit. Angela grabs his shoulder for balance, lowers herself. When she's sitting, the water is all the way to her neck. Normally only a portion of the body has to be suspended but you wanted the crash course...
answer: What will I see? His eyes say it all. Enough.

question: Lie down.
answer: Lie down?

question: You have to be fully submerged.
answer: For how long?

question: As long as it takes. Here -- John cups the back of her neck, holds her face just above the water as she lowers down. Her breathing is picking up. John leans over the tub, looks straight down at her. Last chance... Take a deep one.
answer: All those people... so sad... John nods, helping her understand. ... I've always known... where the bad guys are... where to aim, when to duck... it's not luck... I've always known... Tears stream down her cheeks. John reaches out to touch her when her eyes CLAMP TIGHT in pain --

question: Angela? Eyes snap open and she's off him in a second, runs out. John pries himself from the tile, goes after her.
answer: It was rolling toward him -- not a ball -- something smaller. Shiny. She stops, kneels to the floor. John walks up to join her. Something glints in the catch trough. She reaches down, plucks it up and brings an odd COIN INTO VIEW -- John's face contorts with rage as he takes the familiar coin.

question: Balthazar.
answer: Can you kill him? What about the Balance?

question: That half-breed tipped my scales when he started killing my friends. I'm just adding a little counterweight. John lifts that holy shotgun -- KA CHICK --
answer: What about me? I can't stay here forever. John turns to her -- locks on those eyes. He reaches into his coat pocket as he walks up to her. She shudders as his arms wrap around her face and for a beat they're cheek to cheek. When he pulls back she sees he has clipped Hennessey's AMULET around her neck.

question: Think of it as a bulletproof vest.
answer: So I'm going.

question: You're staying in the car. This shouldn't take long.
answer: Phillip Morris. As Balthazar admires himself, his reflection distorts slightly. The demon in him? He touches his face, does a vowel stretch. His face distorts even further. That's got him moving closer to the mirror. Balthazar's concerned because now his skin appears in motion, rippling as if liquefied. And just when he sees the surface of the mirror BLISTERING and starts to move --

question: How's he doing it? John steps into the trading room, eyes Balthazar rising from the floor. Suit's in shreds, half his face is burned off, but now he's pissed.
answer: This is in direct violation of the Balance!

question: Screw the Balance. John hits him with another BLAST of FLAME -- pins him hard against the wall. How's he doing it, you half-breed shit?! John swings the flame aside so he can KICK Balthazar against the wall. But now his WEAPON SPUTTERS. Shit. Charcoal hand thrusts out, bats away the shotgun and grabs John by the throat. Balthazar rises from the ashes. He may be burned, but he's one tough son of a bitch. Balthazar slides John up a wall by his neck. John can't break his hold. He's choking, frantically rummages through his coat pockets. Comes out with those sacred GOLD KNUCKLES on his right hand. Balthazar tightens his grip and John swings, clocks him across the face. The enhanced punch sends a dizzying ripple throughout Balthazar's body. But he doesn't let go. John is choking, starts whaling on him. Again and again -- each punch weakening this demon more. John finally gets him against the wall. Right arm's tired so he slips the gold knuckles onto his left hand, and with extreme pleasure -- continues punching away. Drives Balthazar to the floor, right to the brink of death.
answer: I will see you very soon...

question: Not really, no.
answer: You can't cheat it this time... you're going back to Hell.

question: True. But you're not. John removes that small BLACK BOX from his coat. Balthazar tries not to be concerned until John unlatches it and removes the one weapon he hardly ever uses -- A Bible.
answer: What are you doing?

question: I'm reading you your last rites. Balthazar reacts. This isn't good.
answer: Your remedial incantations have no relevance to my kind.

question: Aren't you half human? Balthazar doesn't have to answer. You see, that makes you eligible to be forgiven. You do know what it is to truly be forgiven? To be welcomed into the kingdom of God? Balthazar's worst nightmare. A demon in heaven -- love to be a fly on that wall...
answer: You're not a priest, you have no power...

question: -- I escaped hell, who else do you know that has the power to do that?! Balthazar is now doubting his own beliefs. Just tell me how Mammon is crossing over and you can go back to your shithole. Balthazar isn't convinced. John stands -- raises the Bible and starts to read -- 'May the merciful God have mercy on you and grant you the pardon of all your sins...' He places a hand on Balthazar's forehead. Balthazar glares at it as John's voice rises with commanding authority. 'Whosoever sins you remit on earth they are remitted unto them in heaven. I absolve you from -- '
answer: -- It may not even work...

question: How? How's he doing it?! Balthazar looks scared as shit to tell him. 'Grant your child entry into thy kingdom in the name of the Father, and the Son and the Holy Gh -- '
answer: ... Sangre de dio. John is stunned -- did he hear right? Balthazar nods.

question: How?
answer: What killed the Son of God will give birth to the son of the devil. John's mind races and he finally puts it together.

question: He's found the Spear. Balthazar's expression confirms it.
answer: Something's coming... She stares at her surroundings with an increasing sense of dread. Then hears the RUMBLE and TIRES SCREECHING.

question: What happened to staying in the car?
answer: You were in danger.

question: Jesus didn't die from being nailed to a cross. He was finished off by a soldier's spear. He points in the Bible at a detailed painting of the event -- Jesus hanging on the cross -- being pierced by a soldier's spear. It matches that child's drawing John removed from the fridge -- now lying on his seat.
answer: I'm Catholic, John -- I know the crucifixion story.

question: Then you know what this spear would mean to a demon trying to cross over. She doesn't. The stains on its edges? Angela looks back at the painting, notes the liquid flowing from Jesus' wound. Angela can't believe it -- Mammon needed divine assistance -- how's the blood of God's only son? Angela sits stunned for a moment.
answer: So that's it -- he's got everything he needs to escape...

question: Not quite. Twins. Angela gives him a look. Something in the rearview mirror catches his gaze. Here we go -- John floors it and Angela glances out the back window, spots something in the traffic -- bounding over vehicles, hitting the pavement on all fours --
answer: What is that?

question: A hound on the hunt. A blur of muscle and bone leaps over cars at incredible speed -- denting in roofs, CRACKING a WINDSHIELD -- causing general chaos. Cars brake -- SLIDE into each other. And still this thing keeps coming. Hang on -- BARRACUDA slides into an alley, races toward the other end.
answer: Impossible. The beast goes right up the wall and disappears above the building. I lost it. BAM, something lands hard on the roof, denting it a good foot. A huge clawed TALON punches into the sheet metal, starts shredding it right over Angela. Talon thrusts in. Angela dodges it -- her amulet swinging wildly. John HITS the BRAKES and the beast flips off the roof and onto the hood -- right INTO VIEW. A muscular anomaly with eyes that are unmistakably Balthazar's. He lashes against the windshield with an extra appendage. Thank God for safety glass. He jerks back his embedded talon, pulls the entire windshield out with it, smashing it on the hood. GLASS PARTICLES EXPLODE into the car. John throws the car into a spin, slamming the Barracuda into several parked cars. Balthazar is uprooted, is thrown from the car. Angela looks back, sees Balthazar rolling into traffic. He's down --

question: He's not down. Gimme your phone. Angela pulls out her cellular.
answer: This is a private line -- John?!

question: Chaz -- where are you?!
answer: Ah... 3rd and Figueroa.

question: You still got that Sedrallus?
answer: Yeah, but I'm kind of busy right now, John.

question: Dammit, Chaz, I'm trying to save my ass here!
answer: What else is new...

question: Remember the Chalic of Enook incident?
answer: Oh no, no, no, not that, I just paid off this car!

question: West side of the 3rd Street Bridge, say... He checks the speedometer -- 90 mph. ... 2 minutes.
answer: I'm five blocks away! John? John?! Ah... shit. Chaz downshifts, stops in cloud of dust -- Sorry, tour's over. The British start to argue.

question: Of course he's gaining. John PUNCHES the GAS to the floor.
answer: Shit -- shit -- shit --

question: Where's the amulet? WHAM -- something reaches through the roof hole and JERKS HER right out of the car.
answer: What the hell was that?! Both leap onto the concrete rail, lean over and spot a HUGE WINGED SHADOW just as it disappears below the bridge. Chaz is speechless as he turns to John. This is too much. John gives him the out he's been waiting for --

question: We're even. Chaz nods and John leaves him at the rail. He jumps back in the BARRACUDA and PEELS OUT. Chaz watches him race away, looks back at his burning taxi.
answer: Even?

question: Mammon has been trying to climb out of his father's shadow for eons.
answer: And this time he might just make it.

question: Because he's got the Spear?
answer: And the bridge.

question: You're giving this girl way too much credit.
answer: You don't know her.

question: And you do? That would be a first. John swings open a STORAGE ROOM DOOR -- looks in at large-scale relics -- statues, props, etc.
answer: Where's the chair?

question: The chair?
answer: The delicate little number from Sing Sing?

question: It's a fine line that separates a hero from a fool.
answer: I'll take my chances.

question: And taint my establishment with your blood? I don't think so.
answer: Midnite --

question: You know what that device can do to the ill-equipped --
answer: Midnite --

question: -- and even in your most glorious days your brain was never your most powerful attribute --
answer: Where the hell is the chair, you dumb shit?! Midnite just stands there -- his body inflating past it's seven feet. John knows he went too far. That was the cancer talking, you know that, right?

question: Once. John nods.
answer: What's in your bathroom, a Renoir?

question: I have insurance issues. John clears off the seat, starts to sit. Midnite blocks him. You haven't surfed in decades.
answer: Like riding a bike... He tries again. Midnite blocks him again.

question: You'll be lucky to reach an elemental plane.
answer: Then just increase the juice. John tries again. Again Midnite stops him.

question: In your condition your body won't take much.
answer: I just need enough rope to find her.

question: And if you do -- what then?
answer: One goddamn problem at a time -- John shoves past him, plops his ass in the huge chair. His feet dangle off the ground. Midnite stands by, won't help. So John starts strapping himself in the chair. His chest, his ankles. One wrist. He obviously can't strap the other. He looks to the big man. You want me to sign a waiver? Hang on, Angela.

question: Listen to my voice inside... I'll try and guide you out.
answer: Try?

question: Mammon was forced out of that girl when she jumped so unless he found a holding vessel to wait in, he would have fallen back to Hell.
answer: No, he's still here. I'm sure of it.

question: Then watch yourself. He could be in anyone out there. John nods. Midnite lifts a palm of INSECT WINGS in front of his face.
answer: Roach wings? What happened to using lilac pedals -- ?

question: Peter do caelis, Deus, misere nobis. Fili Redemptor mundi, Deus, Miserere nobis... A FLASH turns into a streak behind John's face -- stretching to infinity. Find the possessor and the Spear will be revealed... find them... find them and follow... The flash whips back TOWARD us and John is suddenly somewhere else. He looks O.S.
answer: Ravenscar. The abandoned wing. He's in the boy.

question: You know these won't kill them. John adjusts the flames of a butane heater under a pan. You probably won't even get close enough to use them. In the pan is that RELIGIOUS RELIC he brought from India. It's now MELTING. Midnite has trouble watching it dissolve. And it's not just the boy. John coughs, pours the melted gold into several small casting blocks. You better worry about whoever's helping him. John gives the big guy a glance, dips one of the castings into a pot of water -- HISSSSSS. As much as I admire your blind faith even in the most dire situations -- expecting to just waltz into a facility that is about to become the floodgate of Hell is reaching a bit, even for you. John stops the work, centers on him and Midnite just knows what he's thinking. Midnite sighs, heavily. Well I suppose two fools can die just as easily as one. John almost smiles. Hey, you think I'm trusting you to save the world? John taps the casting and out falls a GOLD-TIPPED BULLET. But we're going to need more than a few magic bullets to get inside. John centers on the Sparkletts bottles positioned around the room. Just like John's. Hmmmm...
answer: That ritual you do with the water, can you do more than one bottle at a time? Midnite raises an eyebrow.

question: Figures.
answer: Okay -- let's cut the scratch and call it a night. Meeting's over. That's got their attention. As entertainment. A few chuckle. John is surprised to see Ellie stepping from the crowd. Still that bundle of sexual energy. Ellie?

question: Okay -- let's cut the scratch and call it a night. Meeting's over. That's got their attention. As entertainment. A few chuckle. John is surprised to see Ellie stepping from the crowd. Still that bundle of sexual energy. Ellie?
answer: Oh, John, you know how much I love it on this side. This was just an opportunity to make it permanent.

question: You think his son will be any different? He'll just turn this place into his own Hell and then where will you to party, Heaven?
answer: No need to get nasty.

question: Never bothered you before.
answer: I am so going to miss our little trysts. Ellie steps closer. The crowd starts to close in with her.

question: I'm sure you will. John pulls out his lighter, holds it up -- flicks it on. Now turn around and take your friends with you. Can he look more ridiculous? I will deport you. All of you. You know I can. John steps back up onto a chair, thrusts the lighter higher --
answer: Oh, John, this is embarrassing. Where is your pride? -- right under a SPRINKLER HEAD.

question: Go to Hell. Ellie looks up just as the sprinklers trigger.
answer: Holy water! Emergency lighting has snapped on -- throwing the room into a strobing nightmare of action. Flashes of human skin melting, revealing snippets of the true demons underneath. It's total pandemonium as their rage is directed toward the only real humans in the room. John and Midnite fling their coats open -- draw their WEAPONS and starts FIRING away at the attacking horde. Sacred bullets cause major damage -- wounds that ripple out through demon bodies. John and Midnite slam back to back -- spinning under the protective shield of a showering sprinkler head -- shooting at all manner of distorted forms that venture into the COLUMN OF SPRAY. One reloads while the other FIRES. It's a hellish form of a turkey shoot. Nothing sacred, nothing spared. John goes for the double doors. Midnite covers him -- blows away another two disintegrating demons. Two come up behind and he spins, takes them down. JOHN gets to the doors, starts to open them when Ellie jumps onto his back -- nails digging in. I'm not going back there!

question: We are what we are, Ellie -- John FIRES over his back, loosens her grip. He grabs hold, shoves her face up into the spray of an overhead sprinkler head. Legs flail about. Midnite comes out of the rain -- grabs John.
answer: Let's go. John drops Ellie to the floor. No more pretty face -- no face at all -- yet the screams still come. John and Midnite get to the doors -- shove through.

question: Barry! Barry looks up, sees the two men rushing toward him. Guns aimed. Let her up!! Let her up!! A beat as John meets Barry's eyes -- realizes he's staring at a frightened child. Barry backs away as -- -- Angela sits up behind John. Water rippling off, straps dangling free. John turns -- locks on her BLACK EYES. Shit -- John thinks fast -- scans the area and sees every mirror in the room has been shattered. So much for the quick fix. He jumps into the water with her, grabs her face and pushes her against the tank walls. This is an exorcism on the fly. Amar natash bow basar! Rescind from the flesh I command thee -- Back to Hell, asshole -- Her body undulates as Mammon's shape tries to come through. Pulsating through her arms, her chest -- her face. Angela BITES into his palm. John recoils. She shoves him off and John hits the tile hard. Angela jumps from the tank, pushes past in a blur. John spins to see Midnite standing right there -- Angela now firmly in his size-twelve grasp.
answer: Finish it.

question: Et separatur a plasmate tuo, Ut num quam laedatur amorsu antiqui serpentes. Into the light I command thee! Into the light I command thee! It takes every ounce of John's life force to keep this spell alive and when he's about to drop from exhaustion the shadow is brought fully into the light -- becomes that familiar shape of WINGS. Gabriel? John is too weak to even be surprised anymore. Figures... Gabriel touches down in front of him. Spear in his hand. And the wicked shall inherit the Earth.
answer: You presume to judge me, John.

question: Betrayal, murder, genocide? Call me provincial.
answer: I am seeking to inspire humankind to be all that was intended.

question: By unleashing Hell on Earth? Good thinking... Gabriel's wings fold behind as he walks around John.
answer: You've had it too easy for too long.

question: So what's a few thousand years of pain, right?
answer: You never deserved to be blessed. You've all been born with a silver spoon in your mouth, never really appreciating the gift you were given so freely -- unconditional love from your creator.

question: And that just bugs the shit out of you.
answer: It's not your fault. Like the animals you are, you never learn unless sufficiently prodded. Pleasure has no lasting effect. But subject you to pain, unpleasantness -- suffering -- and you will take notice, you will fight to overcome, to earn your redemption. That is when you're at your best. Angela's fingernails are starting to darken once again.

question: You're trying to teach us a lesson?
answer: No, I'm giving you the chance to rise above the suffering and truly earn the love of God. The road to salvation begins tonight. Right now. John just stares at this rogue angel, centers on the Spear in his hand. He makes a break for it. Gabriel's wings beat once. The GUST BLOWS John through the double doors, back into the --

question: The time has come at last to collect your soul. Hello, John.
answer: You're early.

question: You're the one show I wouldn't miss.
answer: So I've heard. Satan sees John's slit wrists.

question: I didn't think you'd make the same mistake twice. John looks up at him. You didn't, did you?
answer: ... so how's your son?

question: And why would that matter to you?
answer: ... he's topside...

question: I know.
answer: With Gabriel.

question: Your point?
answer: He's helping your son create his own Hell on Earth...

question: Well, boys will be boys...
answer: He has the Spear of Destiny.

question: This is another one of your cons.
answer: Go look for yourself... Satan is still suspicious. You've waited twenty years for me, what's another twenty seconds? Satan contemplates his remark. Metallic reverberation is overtaken as SOUND and MOTION ramp back to real time --

question: So... what do you want? An extension? John shakes his head, can barely utter a sound...
answer: Isabel...

question: What about her?
answer: ... let her... go home...

question: You would give up your life so she could go to Heaven? John manages a nod... Fine. It's done. Time to go. The sacrifice!! No!!!! THIS ONE You will live, John Constantine, you will live so you'll have the chance to prove that your soul truly belongs in Hell. You will live! Satan eagerly plunges his blazing hands into John's body -- John screams in agony. Satan tears through his tissue -- collecting the cancer, then ripping out a mass of diseased tissue with one vengeful pull. John's final blood-curdling SCREAM ECHOES over --
answer: Human... Gabriel looks up as John retrieves a gun from the wet floor. You don't deserve to be human.

question: Human... Gabriel looks up as John retrieves a gun from the wet floor. You don't deserve to be human.
answer: Then pass judgment on me now. John raises the gun -- puts it to Gabriel's forehead. Do it. Seek revenge. End my life. John's finger nudges the trigger. Kill me! Pull the trigger! Be the hand of God! John pauses, realizes what's happening here...

question: ... and I'll be condemned again...
answer: Do it!

question: You're even worthless as bait. John starts to turn away --
answer: Deny your true nature today, but what of tomorrow, of the tomorrow after that? It is only a matter of time before you end up right back where you belong. It is who you are, Constantine. Damned. John's fist starts behind his back, gains momentum the entire arc until it ends abruptly against Gabriel's face. The ex-angel is propelled all the way to the wall -- SLAMS HARD against the concrete. Body crumples on impact, slides down to the muck. You know this hurt like absolute hell.
